field_edited_text.value:
The Inner Harbor Project

A project of the dimension of the
renewal of the Inner Harbor had to be
phased. Three areas, labeled simply Inner
Harbor Project | (the first phase of 95 acres
next to the water), Inner Harbor West, and
Inner Harbor East were created to imple-
ment the City’s plans.

By 1965 there was recognition that a
specialized management entity was needed
to implement the Inner Harbor program.
The Charles Center Management Office
was transformed into Charles Center-Inner
Harbor Management Inc., a nopeprofit
corporation with ). Jefferson Miller as
chairman. Martin Millspaugh, a Baltimorean
who had been Assistant Commissioner of
the U.S. Urban Renewal Administration and
Deputy General Manager of Charles Cen-
ter, was named President. Walter Sondheim,
Jr., a prominent businessman and former
chairman of the Baltimore Urban Renewal
and Housing Commission, joined the CC/
IH Corp. as Vice-Chairman in 1970. After
Mr. Miller’s death in 1972, Mr. Sondheim
became chairman and Mr. Millspaugh
became President and Chief Executive.

Action came fairly fast— just two years
after Mayor MKeldin launched the Inner
Harbor renewal area. Plans for the Inner
Harbor Project | area were made public
and designated as the first target; voters
approved a $12,000,000 loan for the Inner
Harbor in 1966, and the Urban Renewal
Plan was approved by the Mayor and City
Council in June of 1967.

Baltimore continued its success in tak-
ing full advantage of sources of Federal
funding that had begun in Charles Center.
In 1968 a $22.4 Federal Grant was released
for Inner Harbor Project I. These funds
coupled with the voter approved bond
money, meant that Baltimore could pro-
ceed in earnest with land purchases and
clearance of the old warehouses and other
run down structures.

Although few Baltimoreans were aware
of it at the time, the City had begun the
process of reclaiming the waterfront for
public use. Initial work involved bulkhead-
ing the Inner Harbor shoreline—an expen-
sive proposition — and placing landfill to
provide an expanded western waterfront.

During the same period Mayor Mc-
Keldin appointed David W. Barton as Chair-
man of the City Planning Commission.
Mayor McKeldin mandated Barton to re-
vamp the Department of Planning to better
address the planning issues facing the City.
The Department expanded and together
with the Greater Baltimore Committee,
other planning agencies, consultants and
the private sector prepared a plan for long
range development of the city center. The
plan for MetroCenter, covers over 1,000
acres and details parks and open space,

Light St., looking south, Locust Pt., 1938

i

?:
[ s
b 30K
3

:

residential and commercial areas, and low
and mid-rise structures envisioned for the
harbor. The MetroCenter plan which was
presented in 1968 called for nearly $1 bil-
lion in new investment in the center of the
city, building on the success of the Charles
Center and early Inner Harbor initiatives of
the 1960s.

The years from the early 1970’s into the
1980s were filled with a series of events
which would dramatically alter the physical
appearance of the Inner Harbor and the
population’s perception of Baltimore as a
City.

Construction of a new, expanded
shoreline bulkhead began in the early 70s.
In the midst of this vast construction pro-
ject visitors to the harbor witnessed the first
new buildings and piers in almost 70 years.
When the brick promenade was added on
the north, west, and southern shorelines in
1975, visitors were ready to celebrate the
growing sense of pride in a city slowly
emerging from the difficult years of the
1950s and 1960s. As Charles Center neared
completion in the late 1960’s and early
1970’s the City began to sponsor special
events to attract people back into the
downtown. Jazz on the Plaza, the first City
Fair were intitiated in Charles Center. The
city government led by William Donald
Schaefer, elected Mayor in 1971, expanded
on this strategy of reintroducing Baltimore’s
residents to their waterfront by sponsoring
an ever increasing number of events

throughout downtown with a special focus

on the Inner Harbor. The Mayor knew that
if people had positive feelings about their

82



Maryland Port Administration
